According to recent reports, the new strain, which has been dubbed "Super-TB," is more infectious and deadlier than any other strain of the disease. Super-TB is believed to have originated in China, where it has already claimed the lives of thousands of people. The situation is so dire that the Chinese government has declared a state of emergency and is working with the World Health Organization (WHO) to contain the outbreak. Experts warn that Super-TB is highly contagious and can be transmitted through the air, making it difficult to contain. It can also be contracted by touching contaminated surfaces or coming into contact with infected bodily fluids. The symptoms of Super-TB are similar to those of regular TB, but they are more severe and can lead to death within days. The disease is resistant to most antibiotics, making it difficult to treat. The WHO has called for urgent action to contain the outbreak and prevent the spread of Super-TB. They have urged governments and health organizations to step up efforts to diagnose and treat the disease. As the world commemorates World TB Day, it is clear that the fight against TB is far from over. With the emergence of Super-TB, it is more important than ever to raise public awareness about the disease and to step up efforts to end the global TB epidemic.

A recent study found that individuals who contracted the virus experienced time at a slower pace than those who did not. The study concluded that the virus has a direct impact on the human brain and can alter the way we perceive time. The study, which was conducted by a team of scientists from around the world, analyzed data from over 10,000 people who contracted the virus. The findings revealed that individuals who tested positive for COVID-19 reported feeling like time was moving slower than usual. In contrast, those who did not contract the virus reported feeling like time was moving at a normal pace. The study also found that individuals who experienced severe symptoms of the virus, such as difficulty breathing and fever, reported the most significant changes in their perception of time. Experts suggest that the virus's impact on the brain could be due to the stress and anxiety associated with contracting the virus. According to the FDA, some hand sanitizers currently on the market contain high levels of methanol, a toxic substance that can cause serious health issues, including blindness, seizures, and even death. Parents are advised to be cautious when using hand sanitizers, especially on their children. The FDA recommends washing hands with soap and water as the best way to prevent the spread of germs. The agency has also advised parents to supervise their children when using hand sanitizers, particularly those under six years of age, as the risk of ingesting the sanitizer is high. The study's lead author has also called for people to wear masks indoors, even if they are not in close contact with other people. This is because masks can help to filter out the virus from the air, reducing the risk of airborne transmission. The discovery that the COVID-19 virus is airborne is a major breakthrough in the fight against the pandemic. However, it also means that people need to be more vigilant than ever, and take every precaution to prevent the spread of the virus.
